bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to [Laura Armistead Carter], April 16, 1919

div1.p: Carter writes about his current work and comments on scarlet fever and hysteria.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to [Laura Armistead Carter], April 16, 1919
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MALARIA INVESTIGATIONS
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
U. S. MARINE HOSPITAL
NEW ORLEANS, LA. April 16/19
Dear Laura:
div1.p:
Had an easy trip down rather hot
from Greenville down -Cool enough to be pleas-
ant on my arrival. Was met at the station
by a note from Acker- saying that his family
had gone to Canada & asking me to stay with
him. I was just getting into a bus to go to the
Gruenewald when his messenger reached me.
I accepted - as it prevents the nuisance of
walking back and forth between hotel &
street cars. Carput is absent-gone to open one
of the hospitals left us by the Army near-
Jacksonville Florida, so Acker & myself
are the only medical men sleeping at the reser-
vation- He has 2 new acting assistant
surgeons.
surgeons: No internes of 34 patients.
I then keep him from getting lonesome,
& feel no hesitation at staying at his quar-
ters, I am n Have finished with van Hoven'g
& he left last night. Am now awaiting
answer from Bureau to two wires-one sent
(night letter) Monday & one day message, yes-
terday about noon- We recommended Frank-
now at Gulfport- for van Hovenberg. Pre and asked
if he is available- He will not be. I think, Allen,
at Hattiesburg & Jackson Miss., is next choice
He will be. Then Ropes: then Gorman then
Pincus.
Everything is fixed- between Vault & LeP.,
so that we can present alternative names,
until one will be available - so that matter
so far as my part is concerned is finished
It would have taken 6 weeks of writing
from
from Baltimore. Le P. is in Montgomery to
be back- Friday morning. On Friday morning
the File on Roads O R. R., which you mailed
either last night or this morning- will be
in- If mailed even up to the 3d mail
(afternoon) they will be delivered by Friday
1.302 P. M. He & I will do some thing with
them & then I will leave for Memphis,
should be back next week latter part.

I am sorry not to go to church with you
Good Friday & on Easter. I still thank God
for the Good Friday of 1917, which made Novem-
ber 11 possible.

What of Dorothy, I hope she was not sick
much- S. F: is a treacherous disease - at dive
at times very mild & at times deadly. sometimes
too it has ugly sequelae - suppuration of mid-
dle ear- (Edmond Fontaine) & Brights' Disease-
of Kidneys- wih
which, unlike Y. F. - does frequentlyat times leave
permanent injury- Attacks a different
tissue. I am sorry for her sake for her many
troubles-as well as for our own-

What of Gertrude & Louis? Doubtless the latter
has left for Charleston & the former saw Hamman
yesterday- Did she enter Hospital-or will
yesterday? I do not accept St. Theresa's dic-
tum- that “the vapors” (nenartha hysleria) “is mainly
selfishness”- but it does mainly occur in
people who think too much about themselves
i. e. who are self-centered - but of course frequently
not selfish

Have you seen Clare Jenkins. yet? I hope you got
a chance to do so.

Have not written to Henry- as until this
last night when I was dead tired- it was hot- I did
not know when I would leave- & now he could
scarcely get down by Friday morning.

Love to your Mother & Mary & Jennie- Cool- almost cold- this
morning, & clear & windy.
